text: When Rachel observed that she was not bearing children for Jacob, she became envious of her sister and said to Jacob, “Give me children, or else I shall die!”
Jacob was became angry with Rachel and said, “Am I in the place of God, who has withheld from you the blessing of children?”
Then she said, “Here is my maid Bilhah; go in to her, that she may bear children on my behalf, so that I too may have a family through her.”
So she presented her maid Bilhah to Jacob as a wife, and Jacob was with her.
Bilhah conceived and she bore a son to Jacob.
Rachel said, “God has judged me, and has indeed heard my voice and given me a son.” Therefore she named him Dan.
Rachel’s maid Bilhah conceived once more and bore Jacob another son.
Rachel said, “With great wrestlings have I wrestled with my sister, and I have prevailed.” So she named him Naphtali.
When Leah saw that she was no longer bearing children, she took her maid Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
And Leah’s maid Zilpah gave birth to a son for Jacob.
Leah said, “What good fortune!” So she named him Gad.
Leah’s maid Zilpah gave Jacob another son.
Leah said, “Happy am I! For the daughters will call me blessed.” So she named him Asher.
During the wheat harvest, Reuben went and found mandrakes in the field, and brought them to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”

But she said to her, “Is it a small matter that you have taken my husband? Would you take my son’s mandrakes also?” Rachel replied, “Very well, he shall sleep with you tonight in exchange for your son’s mandrakes.”
When Jacob came in from the fields in the evening, Leah went out to meet him and said, “You must come in to me, for I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.” So he lay with her that night.
God listened to Leah, and she became pregnant and gave birth to a fifth son for Jacob.
Leah said, “God has rewarded me for giving my maid to my husband.” So she named him Issachar.
Leah once more conceived and gave birth to a sixth son for Jacob.
Leah said, “God has endowed me with a good gift; now my husband will honour me, because I have borne him six sons.” So she named him Zebulun.
Afterwards she had a daughter and she named her Dinah.
God took notice of Rachel, and God listened to her and allowed her to conceive.
She conceived and gave birth to a son, and said, “God has removed my shame.”
She named him Joseph, saying, “May the Lord add to me another son.”
After Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Allow me to leave, that I may go to my own place and to my own country.
Return my wives and my children for whom I have served you, and let me go; for you know the service I have provided.”
But Laban said to him, “If I have found favour in your eyes, please stay. I have learned through experience that the Lord has blessed me because of you.”
He said, “Name your wages, and I will pay them.”
Jacob said to him, “You are aware of how I have served you, and how your livestock have prospered under my care.
For you had little before I came, and it has increased greatly, and the Lord has blessed you wherever I turned. But now, when shall I provide for my own household also?”
“What shall I give you?” he asked. Jacob replied, “You shall not give me anything. If you will do this one thing for me, I will continue to shepherd your flock:
Let me pass through all your flock today, removing from it every speckled and spotted sheep, and every dark-coloured lamb, and the spotted and speckled among the goats; these shall be my wages.

So my honesty will answer for me later, when you come to check on my wages. Every one that is not speckled or spotted among the goats, or dark-coloured among the lambs, if found with me, will be considered stolen.”
Laban said, “Agreed, let it be as you have said.”

That same day he removed the streaked and spotted male goats, and all the speckled and spotted female goats, every one that had white on it, and all the dark-coloured lambs, and put them in the care of his sons.
He put a distance of three days’ journey between himself and Jacob, while Jacob continued to tend the rest of Laban’s flocks.
Jacob then took fresh rods of poplar, almond, and plane trees, and peeled white stripes in them, exposing the white of the rods.
He set the rods he had peeled in front of the flocks in the troughs, the watering places where the flocks came to drink, and they mated when they came to drink.
The flocks mated by the rods, and the flocks bore young that were streaked, speckled, and spotted.
Jacob separated the lambs, and made the flocks face towards the streaked and all the dark-coloured animals in Laban’s flock; and he put his own herds apart, and did not put them with Laban’s flock.
Whenever the stronger females were in heat, Jacob would place the rods in the troughs in front of the animals, so they would mate near the rods;
but when the animals were weak, he would not put them there. So the weak animals went to Laban and the strong ones to Jacob.
In this way the man became exceedingly prosperous, and had large flocks, and female and male servants, and camels and donkeys.
